comments.html:
> And still they missed another elephant in the room. Somewhat proves some of my points, I'd say 🤷‍♂️

Which elephant? I think there might be several...

One of the issues is the rather odd release method of Ansible. There's Ansible Community, and Ansible Core. Ansible Core (2.19) is what broke almost every network module in existence, primarily through netcommon, but there was other broken modules, like Arista AVD.

That preceded Ansible Community 12, so there was a time when even though 2.19 was broken, Community 11 which was still the current community release used 2.18.

The difference? Mostly it was "pip3 install ansible" versus "pip3 install ansible-core". The former is what most people tended to use, so they were spared the breakage.

To the Ansible projects credit, the issue was finally addressed and Community 12 was delayed for a while (a month or so IIRC) until some fixes to netcommon were put in place. This... mostly... fixed the issues.

But what a wild ride it was, and easily avoidable.

comments.html:
Ansible engineer here. This blog was recently brought to my attention.

The Ansible team continues to maintain, develop and enhance Ansible Network Automation. The Ansible Project Release 12, which uses ansible-core 2.19, introduced significant changes to the templating engine due to the new data tagging feature. It is most likely that you are encountering this issue because of those changes.

References: https://forum.ansible.com/t/core-2-19-templating-changes-preview-and-testing/40759 https://www.reddit.com/r/ansible/comments/1k7n33q/preparing_your_playbooks_for_core219/

The latest product version, Ansible Automation Platform (AAP) 2.6, is based on ansible-core 2.16:

https://docs.redhat.com/en/documentation/red_hat_ansible_automation_platform/2.6/html-single/release_notes/index

This is the reason users who are running ansible-core versions pinned to the product release have not encountered this issue.

That said, it would have been very helpful for the Ansible Network team to triage and prioritize fixing these issues if they had been raised in the relevant GitHub repositories.

comments.html:
I've long since come to the conclusion that Ansible is far too fast-moving, and consequently too fragile an ecosystem, to rely very much on for large production networks. We still use it for specific targeted things, but increasingly find the vendor-specific modules to be useless for our needs (e.g. can't rename VLANs). I must learn a fundamentally new way to configure my routers and switches about once every 5-10 years. Whereas I must learn a substantially new way of doing <something> with Ansible at least once every six months, if I follow the current release.

I want to spend my time building useful networks, not RE-learning the tool that was supposed to save me time.

It would be enormously helpful if, like most other projects over the last 60 years, the MAJOR version number changed every time there was a breaking change, instead of semi-randomly on any given update.

In short, "move fast and break things" may work in the software world, but the entire philosophy is incompatible with production networks supporting 100k's of users.

comments.html:
I think this is a very reasonable frustration, and it is important to separate the upstream Ansible community project from Ansible Automation Platform as a product.

The Ansible community project moves quickly by design. Collections, modules, and plugins evolve independently and often at different speeds, driven by vendors and individual maintainers. If you track the latest community releases, you are intentionally opting into that velocity, which can result in churn and occasional breakage.

Ansible Automation Platform is intentionally different. It is a curated, enterprise product with a fixed and fully tested set of collections, long support lifecycles, backward compatibility guarantees within a major release, and a clear deprecation and migration process. Most customers pin to a specific AAP release and do not consume upstream changes unless they explicitly choose to.

This is also why the bug being discussed did not actually affect the product. It only existed in the upstream community project. The issue appeared in Ansible Core 2.19, which is newer than what we currently ship to customers in Ansible Automation Platform. Because customers were not yet exposed to that version, it did not surface through normal product usage and was something we missed upstream before it was discovered.

That distinction matters. This is not a case of the product breaking production networks. It is an example of upstream moving faster than the supported platform, which is exactly why the product exists in the first place.

On the broader point about relearning tools, I agree that production networks cannot operate on a move fast and break things model. Ansible Automation Platform is explicitly designed to avoid that philosophy. It exists to let network teams focus on building and operating stable networks while innovation continues upstream at a pace that does not disrupt production environments.
comments.name: Sean Cavanaugh
